habitat_description:
The Gabilan Mountains slender salamander have been recently described after genetic analysis and occur in central coastal California (Jockusch 1996; Jockusch et al. 2001). The northernmost described location for this species is Rodeo Gulch in Santa Cruz County then the distribution expands south through the city of Monterey (Lannoo 2005; Green et al. 2013). 
Habitat of preference includes deeply shaded redwood and mixed coniferous forests, oak woodland and chaparral, and even open grassland with scattered oak. Some of the localities in the north can receive more than 100 cm of precipitation annually, while the southern localities are hotter and drier. For example, populations in the southern Diablo Range in Coalinga Mineral Springs in Fresno County and the northern Temblor Range in Cottonwood Pass, Kern County are restricted to mesic north-facing slopes within the arid oak woodlands and dry chaparral (Lannoo 2005). 

Moist habitats in redwoods and mixed evergreen forests (Stebbins 2003).
